newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak and Hungarian premiers to meet on August 15.
newsitem.headline: Slovak and Hungarian premiers to meet on August 15.

text.p: Cool relations between Slovakia and Hungary showed signs of warming on Monday with the announcement of a meeting between the two prime ministers next month.
The official Slovak TASR news agency said Slovak Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar would meet his Hungarian counterpart Gyula Horn in Gyor, Hungary, on August 15.
The announcement followed a meeting between Slovak Foreign Minister Zdenka Kramplova and Hungary's Laszlo Kovacs in Komarno, Slovakia.
Ties between the two countries have been strained by the problem of Slovakia's treatment of its 500,000-strong Hungarian minority and by a controversial dam project on the river Danube.

A further potential division arose when Hungary received a green light to start accession talks with NATO and a signal from the European Commission that it would be invited to negotiate European Union membership as well.
Slovakia, once a frontrunner to join both groups, was not on the list of potential new members of either.

A statement after the Kramplova-Kovacs meeting said the premiers would focus on European integration and the implementation of an awaited ruling by the International Court in the Hague on the Gabcikovo dam project.
The U.S. and other Western allies have criticised Slovakia over four years of opaque political infighting, its treatment of the Hungarian minority and major shortcomings in media and other reforms.
The last formal meeting between Meciar and Horn was in early 1995 in Paris when they signed a friendship treaty under the auspices of the European Union.
Since then, several planned meetings between the two have failed to materialise.
Kramplova played down differences between the neighbours.
"We who are responsible for Slovak-Hungarian relations are of the opinion that they are better and broader than presented in public," Kramplova told TASR after meeting Kovacs.
